snippet: A federal agency said blindness and death risks were not properly communicated to parents, depriving them of information when deciding whether to participate.
abstract: Office for Human Research Protections finds that 23 prestigious universities failed to inform families of possible fatal side effects in government-financed study involving extremely premature babies; says researchers neglected to communicate to more than a thousand families that risks included increased chances of blindness or death, depriving parents of information when deciding whether to participate with their infants.
lead_paragraph: A federal agency said blindness and death risks were not properly communicated to parents, depriving them of information when deciding whether to participate.

headline.main: Study of Babies Did Not Disclose Risks, U.S. Finds
headline.print_headline: Study of Babies Did Not Disclose Risks, U.S. Finds
